<Link id="l00266" /><CodeLine lineNumber="266"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  ///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00267" /><CodeLine lineNumber="267"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// This function returns, in particular in the case of error reporting</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00268" /><CodeLine lineNumber="268"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// (DI.Severity == \\a DS&#95;Error), so the caller should leave the compilation</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00270" /><CodeLine lineNumber="270"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// need not be correct.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00271" /><CodeLine lineNumber="271"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  ///</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00276" /><CodeLine lineNumber="276"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00277" /><CodeLine lineNumber="277"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Registers a yield callback with the given context.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00278" /><CodeLine lineNumber="278"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  ///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00279" /><CodeLine lineNumber="279"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// The yield callback function may be called by LLVM to transfer control back</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00280" /><CodeLine lineNumber="280"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// to the client that invoked the LLVM compilation. This can be used to yield</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00281" /><CodeLine lineNumber="281"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// control of the thread, or perform periodic work needed by the client.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00282" /><CodeLine lineNumber="282"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// There is no guaranteed frequency at which callbacks must occur; in fact,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00283" /><CodeLine lineNumber="283"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// the client is not guaranteed to ever receive this callback. It is at the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00284" /><CodeLine lineNumber="284"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// sole discretion of LLVM to do so and only if it can guarantee that</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00285" /><CodeLine lineNumber="285"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// suspending the thread won&#39;t block any forward progress in other LLVM</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00286" /><CodeLine lineNumber="286"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// contexts in the same process.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00287" /><CodeLine lineNumber="287"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  ///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00288" /><CodeLine lineNumber="288"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// At a suspend point, the state of the current LLVM context is intentionally</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00289" /><CodeLine lineNumber="289"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// undefined. No assumptions about it can or should be made. Only LLVM</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00290" /><CodeLine lineNumber="290"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// context API calls that explicitly state that they can be used during a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00291" /><CodeLine lineNumber="291"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// yield callback are allowed to be used. Any other API calls into the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00292" /><CodeLine lineNumber="292"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// context are not supported until the yield callback function returns</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00293" /><CodeLine lineNumber="293"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// control to LLVM. Other LLVM contexts are unaffected by this restriction.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00294" /><CodeLine lineNumber="294"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">void</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/llvmcontext/#a26b9a4decea0c52a7225bc63c8166f90">setYieldCallback</a>(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/llvmcontext/#a8671da9544d8cfdf4ccc798e560bdccc">YieldCallbackTy</a> Callback, </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">void</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> &#42;OpaqueHandle);</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00295" /><CodeLine lineNumber="295"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00296" /><CodeLine lineNumber="296"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Calls the yield callback (if applicable).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00297" /><CodeLine lineNumber="297"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  ///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00298" /><CodeLine lineNumber="298"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// This transfers control of the current thread back to the client, which may</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00299" /><CodeLine lineNumber="299"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// suspend the current thread. Only call this method when LLVM doesn&#39;t hold</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00300" /><CodeLine lineNumber="300"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// any global mutex or cannot block the execution in another LLVM context.</span></CodeLine>
